title: Is Google killing your memory?

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the phenomenon where people remember where to find information rather than the information itself?

options.label: A
options.text: The Internet Effect

options.label: B
options.text: The Google Effect

options.label: C
options.text: The Memory Effect

options.label: D
options.text: The Technology Effect

options.label: A
options.text: The hippocampus and the parahippocampal gyrus

options.label: B
options.text: The cerebral cortex and the basal ganglia

options.label: C
options.text: The amygdala and the hypothalamus

options.label: D
options.text: The brainstem and the cerebellum

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Non-declarative memory

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Our brains become less active

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Our brains remain unchanged

options.label: D
options.text: Our brains become more efficient at remembering facts

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential disadvantage of relying on technology to remember information?

options.label: A
options.text: We become collectively smarter

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: We may not have access to information when we need to make split-second decisions

options.label: D
options.text: We become less reliant on our brains

title: The archer's paradox in slow motion

multiple-choice.question: What is the "archer's paradox" in archery?

options.label: A
options.text: The fact that an arrow can fly straight despite being shot from a curved bow.

options.label: B
options.text: The fact that an arrow can hit a target despite being pointed in a different direction.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that an arrow can fly faster than the speed of sound.

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that an arrow can penetrate armor.

multiple-choice.question: How do longbow shooters get around the problem of the archer's paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a completely rigid arrow.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a bendable arrow that can vibrate and bend around the bow.

options.label: C
options.text: By offsetting the bowstring to the side of the bow.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a crossbow instead of a longbow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "spine" of an arrow in archery?

options.label: A
options.text: The weight of the arrow.

options.label: B
options.text: The length of the arrow.

options.label: C
options.text: The stiffness of the arrow.

options.label: D
options.text: The material of the arrow.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important for an archer to know the spine of their arrows?

options.label: A
options.text: So they can shoot the arrow with more force.

options.label: B
options.text: So they can aim the arrow more accurately.

options.label: C
options.text: So they can normalize the wobble of the arrow and hit their target more consistently.

options.label: D
options.text: So they can use the arrow for a longer period of time.

multiple-choice.question: How does Byron Ferguson use science to improve his archery skills?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a special type of arrow that is designed to fly straighter.

options.label: B
options.text: By testing the spine of his arrows to normalize their wobble.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a computer program to simulate the flight of the arrow.

options.label: D
options.text: By practicing his shooting technique for hours every day.

title: Why is blue so rare in nature?

multiple-choice.question: Why are blue colors in animals so rare in nature?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because creating blue pigment requires inventing new chemistry.

options.label: C
options.text: Because blue pigment is not necessary for communication and survival.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Through a combination of pigment and microscopic structure.

options.label: D

title: What if all the ice melted on Earth?

options.text: The sea levels would remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: The sea levels would increase by 10 meters.

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: Why some people don't have an inner monologue

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Inner speech refers to the ability to recall facts and figures.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: To raise brave girls, encourage adventure - Caroline Paul

multiple-choice.question: What was Caroline's initial goal as a kid, and what record did she attempt to break?

options.label: A
options.text: She wanted to set a record in running and attempted to break the 10-mile run record.

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: She wanted to set a record in jumping and attempted to break the 1000-jump record.

options.text: She broke the record and was proud of her achievement.

options.label: B
options.text: She failed to break the record and viewed it as a failure.

options.label: C
options.text: She failed to break the record but later saw it as an example of bravery.

options.text: She broke the record but later regretted the attempt.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: He was indifferent to her actions.

options.label: D
options.text: He was concerned for her safety.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: That fear is always a bad thing and should be eliminated.

options.label: B
options.text: That bravery is only necessary in extreme situations.

options.label: C
options.text: That fear and bravery are mutually exclusive.

options.label: D
